essay:
Josh Allen dropped 38.76 points and somewhere in the group chat, @ToreroGaucho posted a single fire emoji — no caption, no context, just the quiet confidence of a man whose quarterback just turned a Week 1 matchup into a formality. The 2025 season is here, and the preseason power rankings lasted about as long as a Bryce Young starting job.

The numbers don’t lie, but they do love irony. We spent all offseason building a meticulous ranking system — 40% win percentage, 30% points for, 20% recent form, 10% strength of schedule — and the football gods responded by flipping the whole thing upside down like a snow globe. The preseason top three went a combined 1-2. The bottom two? Both won. Your carefully curated tiers? Already on fire.

Start with the Sleeping Giants, ranked eleventh coming in and currently sitting at number one after dropping 151.48 points on MHJTIME’s head. We said your WRs peaked when Fortnite did. We said Derrick Henry and Josh Jacobs had too many career carries. Henry heard us, apparently, because he responded with a 28.7-point performance that suggested the only thing aging about him is his wine collection. Jalen Hurts added 24.28, and suddenly the Island of Misfit WR1s looks more like a private island with bottle service.

Then there’s the Boonist Monks — preseason dead last, Week 1 power rank fourth — who beat Ghastly Grayskull Gang by a casual 34.94 points. That’s not a margin of victory; that’s a restraining order. Lamar Jackson went full video-game mode with 29.36, James Cook contributed 18.7, and @GauchoTrain — the league’s self-appointed instigator of side bets and polls — is absolutely lighting up the group chat right now with receipts. Remember when we said your team could win it all or retire it all? Week 1 chose violence.

Meanwhile, Noble FFT — your preseason number two, the team with the league’s scariest backfield — lost to Rasheeing the Scene by 11.14 points despite Bijan Robinson’s 21.4. Josh Allen’s 38.76 simply doesn’t care about your scouting report. And MHJTIME, our preseason three, put up 142.62 points and still lost. In most leagues, that total wins comfortably. In the Jailyard, that’s a cruel lesson about the schedule gods.

So what do we actually know after one week? That Derrick Henry isn’t done. That Lamar Jackson is still a cheat code. That Josh Allen might be illegal. And that preseason rankings are suggestions, not prophecies.

The group chat has been insufferable since Sunday. The rebuilders are talking trash. The contenders are recalculating. Somewhere, @Chudders is icing another trade offer and smirking.

One week in and nothing makes sense. That’s exactly how dynasty should feel.

rankings.blurb: We wrote your obituary in August. ‘Your WRs peaked when Fortnite did,’ we said. ‘Aging stars on borrowed time,’ we warned. You responded with 151.48 points — the highest total of Week 1 — led by Derrick Henry’s 28.7-point sledgehammer and Jalen Hurts’ 24.28. Even Josh Jacobs chipped in 13.5 from the backfield committee that was supposedly falling apart. The victory over preseason-third MHJTIME wasn’t just a win; it was a statement of intent from a roster the group chat had already eulogized. One week is a small sample. But if this is what borrowed time looks like, you’ll take as many weeks as the football gods give you.

Josh Allen scored 38.76 points. Read that again. The man who was already the QB1 on most boards decided to remind everyone why your floor is higher than most teams’ ceilings. Courtland Sutton added 16.1, De’Von Achane contributed 16.0, and you cruised past Noble FFT by 11.14. We called your WR room a meme waiting to happen — turns out you don’t need elite receivers when your quarterback IS the offense. The group chat consensus was to invest in a steady WR1 rather than another speedster. After Allen’s 38.76, maybe the real investment was already on the roster all along.

You opened the defense of your 2024 title exactly the way champions should — with a workmanlike 143.72-point victory over Chudders. Garrett Wilson (19.0), Puka Nacua (18.1), and a surprisingly strong Jacksonville defense (16.0) carried your squad while the rest of the roster provided that maddening consistency we’ve come to expect. Runner-up in 2022, runner-up again in 2023, champion in 2024 — and now a quiet 1-0 start in 2025. Your floor is nice, we said. Your ceiling might be drywall. But drywall keeps winning games while other teams’ marble ceilings crumble. Somewhere Tony Pollard had another three-yard carry and the chat still hasn’t let it go.

From dead last in the preseason to top four in Week 1 — and you didn’t even need a close game to do it. Lamar Jackson’s 29.36-point eruption anchored a 144.36-point week that buried Ghastly Grayskull by nearly 35 points. James Cook added 18.7, Jaxon Smith-Njigba contributed 13.9, and even the aging Travis Kelce managed 11.7 of quiet production. We said your team could win it all or retire it all. Week 1 picked the winning option. The group chat’s most prolific instigator of side bets has fresh ammunition for at least seven days. Enjoy the receipts while they’re warm, because at 27.2 years average age, every win feels like a bonus round.

Relax — a 135.88-point win over Father Time is exactly what the preseason favorite is supposed to do, even if it doesn’t generate headlines. Nick Bosa led the way with 19.0, Saquon Barkley added 16.4, and Drake Maye’s 15.28 at quarterback was... fine. Not electric. Not disastrous. Just fine. The problem isn’t the result; it’s that your All-Pro team — the roster that could headline Coachella — finished sixth in total points this week. The group chat isn’t teasing you about taxi squad debates this week; they’re asking why CeeDee Lamb only put up 14.5. One week doesn’t make a season, but the franchise everyone measures themselves against better start measuring up to its own billing.

Patrick Mahomes dropped 26.02, Christian McCaffrey reminded everyone he’s still very much alive with 19.2, and you quietly dispatched Burden of Etienne-y Woody by 11.4. It’s not flashy. It won’t dominate the group chat. But the 2022 inaugural champion grinding out a W with its two best players is exactly the kind of boring, effective football that keeps you dangerous. Remember trading for Mahomes in 2023? That deal keeps paying dividends even as the rest of your roster creaks toward the cliff. You need a tight end with a pulse — we’ve said it, the chat has said it, your roster screams it — but for now, the Voltron receivers and your two stars are enough.

Here’s the cruel math of dynasty: you scored 142.62 points and lost. Most weeks, that total cruises to a W — but you drew the one opponent on the schedule who put up 151.48. Myles Garrett’s 22.0 and Jayden Daniels’ 20.12 were both excellent, and Marvin Harrison Jr. added 15.6 — your historic WR trio showed up. The running back room, though, was exactly the concern we flagged: Chuba Hubbard managed 16.4 but the depth behind him remains patchwork. Toilet-bowl runner-up in 2023, semifinalist in 2024 — don’t let 2025 become the year you had the talent but not the luck. This loss was a scheduling coin flip, not a referendum on your roster.

Sure, you lost, but 133.82 points from a rebuilding roster is actually pretty encouraging. Justin Herbert threw for 27.92 fantasy points — the third-best QB performance of the week — and your rookie Emeka Egbuka exploded for 21.6. The young RB duo of Jeanty (11.0) and Croskey-Merritt (14.2) showed flashes too. You lost to the defending champion; there’s no shame in that. Your war chest is still overflowing with draft picks and the chat is still joking about you icing trade offers. Keep icing them. The rebuild is on schedule, and if Egbuka is real, you might have found your WR1 of the future for free.

From the league’s scariest backfield to Week 1’s ninth-ranked team — not exactly the start you drew up on the whiteboard. Bijan Robinson held up his end with 21.4, and Breece Hall added 15.5, but Josh Allen happened. The 38.76-point buzzsaw from Rasheeing the Scene made your 132.92 feel pedestrian. Jordan Love’s 15.92 was fine, Ricky Pearsall added 13.8, but fine doesn’t beat a quarterback who just put up the highest individual score of the week. We said an elite tight end and receiver depth would keep you out of contention until you fix them. After Week 1, add an answer for Josh Allen to that shopping list. Bijan and Breece are still gods. But gods need a supporting cast.

Some things stay consistent even when the rankings go haywire, and you sitting at tenth is one of them. A 120.68-point output against General Ken-obi was always going to be a tough sell, and your roster didn’t do itself any favors. Brock Purdy led with 18.78, Kyle Hamilton contributed 13.5 from the DB slot, and Jaylen Warren managed 12.9. Brian Thomas Jr. — the 2024 rookie class headliner you’re banking on — didn’t crack your top five scorers this week. We said the chat would love your random 180-point weeks and ignore the rest. Week 1 was the rest.

Justin Jefferson, the top-three overall asset who was supposed to carry you to respectability, put up 12.8 points. Your best scorer was Kyler Murray at 18.32, followed by the Denver Broncos defense at 18.0 and kicker Ka’imi Fairbairn at 14.9. When your defense and your kicker both outscore your franchise wide receiver, the alarm bells should be deafening. The loss to Legion of Bouz by 11.4 isn’t surprising; we flagged your quarterback roulette and running-back triage unit in the preseason. You scored 120.32, second-worst in the league. Those Jefferson trade rumors floating around the chat might be getting louder after this one.

This is what happens when your pick stash is bigger than your production. Week 1’s low scorer at 109.42, a 34.94-point beatdown at the hands of the Boonist Monks, and a C.J. Stroud who managed just 9.72 points. Deebo Samuel’s 19.1 and Brock Bowers’ 13.8 tried their best, but when your kicker Cam Little is your second-highest scorer at 16.8, you know the depth chart has problems. We wrote that the pundits in the chat love to remind you that picks don’t score points. They’re going to be especially loud this week. You cashed in capital to load up on explosive young runners — none of them exploded in Week 1. The blueprint is still sound, but blueprints don’t win matchups.

confessionals.text: I looked at the preseason rankings. Eleventh. I saw the essay: ‘aging stars,’ ‘borrowed time,’ ‘Island of Misfit WR1s.’ I read it out loud to Derrick Henry. I don’t know if he can hear me through the phone, but he scored 28.7 so I’m going to keep doing it every week.

The Boonist Monks beat me by 35 points. My kicker was my second-highest scorer. C.J. Stroud had 9.72 points. I have a mountain of draft picks and none of them played this week. I’d like to formally request that the group chat skip roasting me for at least 48 hours. The producer says no.

I scored 142 points. One hundred and forty-two. Do you know how many teams in this league would kill for 142? Eleven. Eleven teams would kill for 142. I played the one team that scored 151. Myles Garrett had 22. Jayden Daniels had 20. The WR trio showed up. And I still lost. Someone check if there’s a Bad Luck clause in the bylaws.

Dead last in the preseason. DEAD. LAST. And now I’m sitting here at number four after dropping 144 on Grayskull’s head. Lamar went off, Cook went off, even Kelce chipped in. The group chat said my team could retire at any moment. Well, we didn’t retire today.

mailbag.question: Dear Commish: My preseason top-three team scored 142.62 and lost. Is it legal to protest a scheduling algorithm? Asking for @rango_.
mailbag.answer: It’s Week 1. You drew the one team that scored higher. If you’re protesting scheduling after one loss, wait until Week 6 when the matchups get truly cruel. That’s when the real panic starts.

mailbag.question: From the group chat: @GrayskullXX, we were told picks don’t score points. When do the picks start scoring points?
mailbag.answer: Respectfully: when you draft them. Your two best dynasty assets — Brock Bowers and C.J. Stroud — combined for 23.5 points. That’s a rounding error for Josh Allen.

mailbag.question: @zbcowan asks: Can I get the preseason rankings committee’s home address? I just want to talk.
mailbag.answer: The committee stands by ranking you eleventh. The committee also acknowledges that Derrick Henry scoring 28.7 in Week 1 was not in the model. The committee is currently updating the model.

mailbag.question: Dear Commish: Is Josh Allen legal?
mailbag.answer: Technically yes. Morally? Debatable. The man put up 38.76 in a format where 20 is a good week. There should be a luxury tax on quarterbacks.

mailbag.question: From the group chat: We set our preseason rankings using a formula — 40% win pct, 30% points, 20% form, 10% SOS. After one week, should we just use 100% vibes?
mailbag.answer: The formula is sound. The formula needs more than seven days of data. But between you and me, 100% vibes would have ranked the Boonist Monks higher than twelfth, so maybe the vibes know something.

bits.title: Nobody Believes In Us Award
bits.text: The Sleeping Giants, who went from ‘Island of Misfit WR1s’ to Week 1’s top scorer in the time it takes Derrick Henry to break a tackle. @zbcowan hasn’t posted in the group chat yet. That’s how you know he’s savoring it.

bits.title: The Ewing Theory Alert
bits.text: The Boonist Monks dropped 144.36 despite Tyreek Hill being relatively quiet — didn’t crack the top five scorers. Lamar Jackson at 29.36 and James Cook at 18.7 carried the load. When your supposed third-best player doesn’t show up and you still win by 35, the theory is alive and well.

bits.title: Is MHJTIME the New 2019 Saints?
bits.text: Scored enough to beat most of the league and still lost to the one team on the schedule that went off. The dynasty equivalent of going 13-3 and losing in the first round. Heartbreaking, but fixable — as long as the schedule cooperates from here.

bits.title: Things I Believe But Can’t Prove
bits.text: Justin Herbert is going to be the steal of the 2025 season and Chudders’ rebuild is six months ahead of schedule. Emeka Egbuka’s 21.6-point debut was not a fluke. Book it.

bits.title: Overheard in the Chat
bits.text: ‘Henry is washed’ — everyone, August 2025. ‘Henry is BACK’ — also everyone, September 2025. The duality of the Jailyard group chat, captured in two sentences and a four-week gap.

picks.blurb: Lamar Jackson just dropped 29.36 against a better opponent than this. Burden’s 120.32 was second-worst in the league, and their best scorer was a quarterback they don’t fully trust. The Monks are riding momentum and an aging core that apparently didn’t get the age cliff memo. Monks cover comfortably.

The defending champ showed consistency in Week 1 with 143.72, but Noble’s roster is too talented to stay at ninth. Bijan Robinson (21.4) and Breece Hall (15.5) are matchup-proof, and without Josh Allen on the other side this week, 132 points starts looking a lot better. Noble bounces back in a tight one.

Mahomes (26.02) and McCaffrey (19.2) versus a team whose kicker was its second-highest scorer. This shouldn’t be competitive. But Brock Bowers is a matchup nightmare and young rosters can explode any given week. Take the Bouz, but don’t expect another 35-point blowout.

Allen’s 38.76 was an outlier, but even his floor is QB1. Chudders is rebuilding and Herbert’s 27.92 won’t carry every week. The spread feels right — Rasheeing wins but Chudders’ young core keeps it respectable. Achane and Irving do enough alongside Allen.

Two 0-1 teams with very different ceilings. MHJTIME’s 142.62 in a loss proves the firepower is there — Jayden Daniels, Myles Garrett, and the WR trio are real. Father Time’s 120.68 doesn’t inspire confidence. MHJTIME wins, but both teams’ floors are unpredictable enough to make this one squirmy.

The marquee matchup of Week 2: preseason number one versus the new number one. The Sleeping Giants just hung 151.48 on MHJTIME, but General Ken-obi’s roster is deeper at every position. Barkley, Lamb, and the defensive studs should be enough — but if Henry goes off again, all bets are off. We’ll take the General at home by a hair.

special_picks.teaser: Boonist Monks -3.0 / Rasheeing the Scene -1.0 — two favorites teased down to near-pickem spreads against rebuilding opponents
